questions.question_text_1: Consider a server that has an Intel i5 processor, 64 GB RAM, 1 TB Hard disk with 3 Gbps network connection. If a client accesses a web page, it requires 1.5 MB. Calculate the maximum number of such requests per second the server can handle. (Use relations: 1 Byte = 8 bits, 1 MB = 1000 B, 1 GB = 1000 M and so on).

questions.question_text_1: The speed vs. throughput characteristics of a typical HDD is shown in the figure below. If this HDD is to be used as a replacement of an SSD whose read/write speed is 450 MB/s. At what speed (in RPM) should the disk of HDD rotate with to deliver the same performance as that of the SSD?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the core topics, concepts, and equations from the exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships between key areas. --- ### **Core Topics & Concepts** #### **1. Web Development Fundamentals** - **URL Structure**: - Protocol (e.g., `https`), Domain Name (e.g., `www.example.com`), Path (e.g., `/home`), Query Parameters (e.g., `?user=Mad1`). - **Key Equation**: None (descriptive only). - **HTTP Methods**: - `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`. - **Flask Routes**: Use `@app.route` with `methods=['POST']` for handling form submissions. - **Flask Templating (Jinja2)**: - Syntax: `{{ variable }}`, `{% for item in list %}`, `{% if condition %}`. - **Example**: ```jinja2 {% for item in my_list %} {% if item|length % 2 == 0 %}

{{ item }}

{% else %}

{{ item }}

{% endif %} {% endfor %} ``` - **Flask-SQLAlchemy**: - **Queries**: - `Model.query.filter_by(field=value).all()` → Returns a list. - `Model.query.get(id)` → Returns a single object or `None`. - `Model.query.filter(Model.field.like('F%'))` → Pattern matching. - **Updates**: ```python workers = Workers.query.filter_by(Gender='Female').all() for worker in workers: worker.Salary += 500 db.session.commit() ``` - **Relationships**: - One-to-Many: `db.relationship("ChildModel", backref="parent")`. - Foreign Keys: `db.ForeignKey("parent_table.id")`. - **Flask-RESTful**: - **Resource Classes**: Define `get`, `post`, `put`, `delete` methods. - **Request Parsing**: ```python parser = reqparse.RequestParser() parser.add_argument('Name', required=True, help='Name is required') args = parser.parse_args() ``` - **Marshalling**: Use `@marshal_with` to format output. --- #### **2. HTML/CSS** - **CSS Selectors**: - ID (`#id1`), Class (`.class1`), Element (`p`). - **Specificity**: Inline > Internal > External. - **Box Model**: - `margin`, `border`, `padding`, `content`. - **Flexbox/Grid**: Not covered in questions but implied for layout. --- #### **3. Testing (Pytest)** - **Fixtures**: - Reusable setup code with `@pytest.fixture`. - **Example**: ```python @pytest.fixture def order(): return ["Pens", "Books"] def test_order(order): order.append("Pencils") assert order == ["Pens", "Books", "Pencils"] ``` - **Test Isolation**: - Each test runs with a fresh fixture instance. --- #### **4. Performance & Algorithms** - **Time Complexity**: - **Sorting**: `O(n log n)` (e.g., Merge Sort). - **Scaling Requests**: - Bandwidth calculation: - **Equation**: ``` Bandwidth (Gbps) = (Requests × Size per Request × 8 bits) / (10^9 bits/second) ``` - **Example**: For 12,500 requests of 180 KB each: ``` 12,500 × 180 × 1000 × 8 = 18 × 10^9 bits → 18 Gbps. Increase = 18 - (10,000 × 150 × 8 / 10^9) = 18 - 12 = 6 Gbps. ``` - **HDD/SSD Throughput**: - **Equation**: Throughput ∝ RPM (for HDDs). - **Example**: To match 450 MB/s SSD speed, HDD RPM must be ~28,800 (extrapolated from graph). --- #### **5. Database (SQLite)** - **Indexing**: - `CREATE UNIQUE INDEX ON table (column) WHERE condition;`. - **Queries**: - `SELECT * FROM table WHERE Age > 18;`. - **Relationships**: - Parent-Child: `state.cities` (list of child objects), `city.state` (parent object). --- #### **6. Networking** - **Bandwidth vs. Throughput**: - **Bandwidth**: Maximum data transfer rate (bps). - **Throughput**: Actual achieved rate (affected by latency, protocol overhead). - **Server Capacity**: - **Equation**: ``` Max Requests/Second = Bandwidth (Gbps) / (Request Size × 8 bits) ``` - **Example**: For 3 Gbps and 1.5 MB requests: ``` 3 × 10^9 / (1.5 × 10^6 × 8) ≈ 250 requests/second. ``` --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph** ```mermaid graph TD %% Web Development A[Web Development] --> B[Flask] A --> C[HTML/CSS] A --> D[HTTP Methods] B --> B1[Routing] B --> B2[Templating Jinja2] B --> B3[Flask-SQLAlchemy] B --> B4[Flask-RESTful] B1 --> B1a[GET/POST/PUT] B2 --> B2a[Loops/Conditionals] B3 --> B3a[Queries] B3 --> B3b[Relationships] B4 --> B4a[Resource Classes] B4 --> B4b[Request Parsing] C --> C1[CSS Selectors] C --> C2[Box Model] %% Testing E[Testing] --> E1[Pytest] E1 --> E1a[Fixtures] E1 --> E1b[Test Isolation] %% Performance F[Performance] --> F1[Time Complexity] F --> F2[Bandwidth] F1 --> F1a[O(n log n)] F2 --> F2a[Gbps Calculation] %% Database G[Database] --> G1[SQLite] G1 --> G1a[Indexing] G1 --> G1b[Relationships] %% Networking H[Networking] --> H1[Throughput] H1 --> H1a[RPM vs MB/s] ``` ```mermaid graph TD %% Connections Between Topics B3b -->|One-to-Many| G1b B4a -->|POST/PUT| D F2a -->|Requests/Second| H1a C1 -->|ID/Class| B2a E1a -->|Reusable Data| B ``` --- ### **Key Equations Summary** | **Topic** | **Equation** | **Example** | |-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------| | Bandwidth (Gbps) | `(Requests × Size × 8) / 10^9` | 12,500 × 180KB → 6 Gbps increase. | | Requests/Second | `Bandwidth (bps) / (Request Size × 8)` | 3 Gbps / (1.5 MB × 8) ≈ 250 requests/sec. | | Time Complexity (Sort) | `O(n log n)` | 1200 entries: ~273 sec (scaled from 100 sec).| | HDD Throughput | `Throughput ∝ RPM` (empirical from graph) | 450 MB/s → 28,800 RPM. | --- ### **Exam Tips** 1. **Flask**: Focus on routing, templating, and SQLAlchemy queries. 2. **HTML/CSS**: Understand selector specificity and box model. 3. **Performance**: Memorize bandwidth/throughput equations. 4. **Testing**: Fixtures are reused per test; changes in one test don’t affect others. 5. **Database**: Practice `filter_by`, `get`, and relationship queries.
